newsitem.title: USA: Clinton concerned about image in alien movie.
newsitem.headline: Clinton concerned about image in alien movie.

text.p: Look out Hollywood, President Bill Clinton is upset at the way he is being portrayed in a new hit movie, "Contact."
In the movie about earth contact with an extraterrestrial civilisation, Clinton is pictured talking about the potential significance of the breakthrough.
It was actually sound bites from remarks he made last summer when scientists announced a meteorite from Mars contained a possible sign of life on the red planet.
White House spokesman Mike McCurry said on Monday the movie went beyond typical satire and parody for which Clinton is caricatured frequently.
The White House told the director its policy prohibits the use of the president for commercial purposes.

"You have manipulated images of the president's public statements, taken them out of the context in which they were uttered, and adapted them to fit the plot of your film," White House counsel Charles Ruff wrote in a sternly worded letter to "Contact" director Robert Zemeckis dated July 11.
"By appropriating President Clinton's image and words in this manner, you have essentially given him a role in your film without his authorisation," he said.
The letter did not threaten a lawsuit. White House officials said the message was they would not like to see this done again in another movie.
In a recent interview, Zemeckis said he needed no White House consent to digitally superimpose Clinton's image into scenes with the film's stars, Jodie Foster, Angela Bassett and James Woods.
"No, the president is in the public domain. He works for us. I hear he's a big fan of Jodie's," Zemeckis said.
Zemeckis similarly incorporated footage of late presidents John Kennedy, Lyndon Johnson and Richard Nixon for scenes in the 1994 Oscar-winning film "Forrest Gump."
The White House has also feuded with a local fast food firm over radio advertising in which an actor who sounds a lot like Clinton calls in to order a sandwich.
